turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Don't forget your CDs.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Those aren't mine.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Sure they are.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: They're not really, though, are they? I know you bought them for me, and that was really sweet of you, but that was when you were trying to turn me into you.  I can't take them, I know they'd just sit around staring at me, and I'd feel embarrassed by them and... they don't fit in with the rest of what's mine, do you understand?  That Sting record you bought for me... that was a present for me.  I like Sting and you hate him.  But the rest of this stuff...  Who the hell is Nick Lowe?  Or Gram Parsons?  Or the Boredoms?  I don't know these people.  I...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Okay, okay.  I get the picture.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I'm sorry to go on about it.  But, I don't know, there's a lesson here somewhere, and I want to make sure you get it.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I got it.  You like Sting but you don't like Gram Parsons, because you've never heard of him.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You're being deliberately obtuse.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I guess I am.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Well, think about it.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Hey, how ya doin'?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Guess who I just saw, right by my store?  Ian.  In Starbuck's.  Neat, huh?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I can't talk right now.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: God, that's a cold and a half.  Maybe you should bet back in bed.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Are you alright?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Pigsty.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Don't worry about it.  Just get into bed.  Worry about that when you're better.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Pig died.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Who the fuck's Pig?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: My dad died.  My dad, my dad.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No, no.  When are you going home?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: In a minute.  When I get it together.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Me?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: My dad liked you.  And Mom never told him we'd split, because he wasn't up to it and... oh, I don't know.  I don't really understand it.  I think she thinks he'll be able to see what's going on.  It's like...  He's been through so much, what with dying and everything, that she doesn't want to upset him any more than she has to.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Do you want me to be there?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I don't care.  As long as you don't expect me to hold your hand.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Look, are you coming or not?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yes, of course.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Liz'll give you a lift.  She knows where to go and everything... I don't have time to talk, Rob.  I've got too much to do.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Sure.  I'll see you on Friday.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Are you going to lie in that flower bed all night?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Uh... No.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You're soaking.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Mmnn.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You're also an idiot.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I can see why you say that.  Look, I'm sorry.  I really am.  The last thing I wanted was... that's why I left, because... I lost it, and I didn't want to blow my top in there, and... look, the reason I fucked everything up was because I was scared.  I just wanted you to know, that's all.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Thank you.  I appreciate it.  I can't reciprocate.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I didn't mess things up because I was scared.  I slept with Ray because I was sick of you.  And I needed something to snap me out of it.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Sure, I understand.  Look, I don't want to take up any more of your time.  You get back, and I'll wait here for a bus.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I don't want to go back.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What do you want to do?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: C'mon.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: When are you going back?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I don't know.  Sometime.  Later. Listen, Rob, would you have sex with me?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I want to feel something else than this.  It's either that or I go home and put my hand in the fire.  Unless you want to stub cigarettes out on my arm.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I've only got a couple left.  I'm saving them for later.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: It'll have to be sex, then.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Hello.  It doesn't seem so long ago that I looked at you from here.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I knew there was a reason I wore a skirt today.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You know, with Ray...

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Oh, Rob, we're not going to go through that again.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No, no.  It's not... are you still on the pill?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Yes, of course.  There's nothing to worry about.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I didn't mean that.  I mean... was that all you used?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Look, we can do other things.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I lived with you.  You were my partner just a few weeks ago and now you're worried I might kill you, and you're entitled to worry.  Isn't that a terrible thing?  Isn't that sad?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Laura...

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I'm too tired not to go out with you.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: So if you had a bit more energy we'd stay split.  But things being how they are, what with you wiped out, you'd like us to get back together.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Everything's too hard.  Maybe another time I would have the guts to be on my own, but not now I don't.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What about Ian?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Ray's a disaster.  I don't know what that was all about, except that sometimes you need someone to lob into the middle of a bad relationship like a hand grenade, I guess, and blow it all apart.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Mission accomplished.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I know it's not very romantic, but there will be romance again at some stage, I'm sure.  I just... I need you, Rob.  That's it.  And we know each other and we care for each other, and you've made it clear that you want me back, so...

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Let's go home.  Okay?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: C'mon.  I want to know.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Want to know what, exactly?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What it was like.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: It was like sex.  What else could it be like?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Was it like good sex or was it like bad sex?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: What's the difference?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You know the difference.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Look, we're okay now.  We just had a nice time.  Let's leave it at that.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Okay, that's cool, okay.  But the nice time we just had... was it nicer, as nice, or less nice than the nice times you were having a couple of weeks ago?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Oh, c'mon, Laura.  Just say something. Lie, if you want.  It'd stop me asking you questions and it'd make me feel better.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Well I was gonna lie and now I can't, because you'd know I was lying.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Well why the fuck would you want to lie, anyway?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: To make you feel better.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Oh, great...

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Look, Rob.  If great sex was as important as you think it is, and if I was having great sex with him, then we wouldn't be lying here now. And that is my last word on the subject, okay?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: ... Like Mexico.  Or Jamaica.  Or New York, even.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Hey, great idea.  What I'll do is, tomorrow I'll get a hold of a box full of mint Elvis Presley 78s on the Sub label, and I'll pay for it that way.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I'll pay for you.  Even though you owe me money.  We have to do something with the money I earn.  I need to. I deserve it.  You can just think of it as winning the lottery.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Fantastic.  The Girlfriend Lottery.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Money does not matter.  I do not care how much you earn.  I'd just like you to be a little happier in your work, but beyond that you can do what you like.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: But it wasn't supposed to be like this.  When I met you we were the same people and now we're not, and...

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: How?  How were we the same people?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Well, you were the kind of person who came to the Artful Dodger and I was the kind of person who deejayed at the Artful Dodger.  You wore jeans and T-shirts, and so did I.  And I still do, and you don't.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Because I'm not allowed to.  I still do, after work.  So, what?  Should we just break up?  Is that what you're saying?  Because if you are, I'm going to run out of patience.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No, but...

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: But what?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: But why doesn't it matter that we're not the same people we used to be?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You haven't changed so much as a pair of socks in the years I've known you.  If we've grown apart, then I'm the one who's done the growing, and all I've done is change jobs.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: And hairstyles and clothes and attitude and friends and...

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I can't go to work with my hair dyed pink.  And I can afford to go shopping more now, and I've met a couple people I like over the last year or so.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You're tougher.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: More confident, maybe.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Harder.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Less neurotic.  Are you intending to stay the same for the rest of your life?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'm alright.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Yeah, you're alright.  But you're certainly not happy.  So what happens if you get happy?  And yes I know that's the title of an Elvis Costello album, I use the reference deliberately to catch your attention. Should we split up because I'm used to you being miserable?  What happens if you, I don't know, start you're own record label, and it's a success? Time for a new girlfriend?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You're being stupid.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: How?  What would be the difference between you having a record label and me going from legal aid to private practice?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: All I'm saying is, you have to allow for things to happen to people, most of all to yourself.  Otherwise, what's the use?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No use.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Hi.  What are you doing?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Wanna go to dinner?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: At Paul and Miranda's.  Paul from work.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Oh.  Well.  We don't really get along. Paul and I.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I know.  But you've never met.  It just seems like a stone unturned in your relationship with him.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Ha.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You did that deliberately.  You knew all along I'd like them.  It was a trick.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I tricked you into meeting some people you'd think were great.  I thought it would be fun to introduce you to someone with a Tina Turner album and then see whether you still felt the same way.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I called Dan Koretzky because he --

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Has Drag City Records, I know, I know.  You told Dan Koretzky about this?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Yeah, and he said it's a good way to break out a record.  Especially for what he said, and I quote, "would be a highly anticipated event, locally." He helped me put out a press release.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: WHAT?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Just local, of course.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: And the "triumphant return of DJ Rob Gordon?" "Triumphant?" "Return?"

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I had that idea when I was living with Ian and it was such a good idea that I was annoyed we weren't together anymore.  It might even be why I came back.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You had no right.  Supposing I was doing something that couldn't be cancelled?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: What do you ever do that can't be cancelled?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: That's not the point.  I mean, what if the single isn't done in time?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Barry said its done.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Barry?  Barry knows about this?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Yeah.  His band is playing a set.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: They'll go on early.  Nobody will even be there yet and I told them they can't play for more than a half hour.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It's no joke.  I'm responsible for what happens, you know.  Embarrassment aside, there's a lot of money and effort in this, at least by my standards.  I have to put down a deposit for the room.  I have to pay the pressing plant for the records, sleeve them, sticker them --

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: We took care of that.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'm sorry I've been acting like a jerk.  I do appreciate what you've done for me, and I know you've done it for the best possible reasons, and I do love you, even though I act like I don't.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: That's okay.  You seem pissed off all the time, though.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I know.  I don't get it.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Are you worried about tomorrow night?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Not really.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Are you going to talk to me, or shall I get my paper out?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'm going to talk to you.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: What are you going to talk to me about?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'm going to talk to you about whether you want to get married or not.  To me.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Ha ha ha.  Hoo hoo hoo.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I mean it.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Oh, well thanks a fucking bunch.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I'm sorry.  But two days ago you were in love with that girl who interviewed you for The Reader, weren't you?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Not in love, exactly, but...

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Well forgive me if I don't think of you as the world's safest bet.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Would you marry me if I was?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: No.  Probably not.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Right.  Okay, then.  Shall we go?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Don't sulk.  What brought all this on?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Very persuasive.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Are you persuadable?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: No.  I don't think so.  I'm just curious about how one goes from making tapes for one person to marriage proposals to another in two days. Fair enough?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Fair enough.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'm just sick of thinking about it all the time.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: This stuff.  Love and marriage.  I want to think about something else.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I've changed my mind.  That's the most romantic thing I've ever heard. I do.  I will.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Shut up.  I'm only trying to explain.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I mean, maybe you're right.  But were you really expecting me to say yes?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I dunno.  Didn't think about it, really.  It was the asking that was the important thing.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Well, you've asked.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'm an idiot.  I should have played the record first.  This place is about to get burned down.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: It's gonna be fine.  These people are ready for anything.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Rob here.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Hey.  It's Liz.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What's happenin'.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: You called this morning?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yeah.  I just wanted to thank you for that message last night.  It made me feel like... like less of an asshole.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: How're you holding up?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Actually, I'm fine.  I'm great. Last night I got to thinking, "you know what?  Maybe it is time to move on.  Maybe we're just not right for each other.  Or maybe we are.  But time will tell and at this point I'm going to be fine with whatever's meant to be." You know?

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Yeah.  Like I said, I don't want to take sides.  And I like Laura with you.  She's more fun, more open. You guys are good together.  I just wish you two could, I don't know.  I don't think much of this Ian guy --

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What's the -- hey, Liz --

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: -- No, no, no, don't even.  I talked to Laura, Rob.  I talked to her and she gave me a little background. And you're a fucking ASSHOLE.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: To think I sympathized with you for two seconds!  Poor Rob!  Laura left him out of nowhere for the schmuck upstairs.  You let me believe that!

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It's true!

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Rob!  Two years ago you got Laura pregnant; you then proceeded to cheat on her!  You borrowed money from her and never paid a dime back!  And then, just a few weeks ago, you told her you were unhappy with her and were "kind of looking around for somebody else!"

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Well she --

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: So the minister says nice things, and then, what, we all troop outside and they bury him?

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: It's a crematorium.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You're kidding.  A crematorium? Jesus.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: What difference does it make?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Is Ray going?

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: No.  They don't know him.  And Ken liked you.  Rob, Ken didn't die for your benefit, you know.  It's like everybody's a supporting actor in the film of your life story.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Isn't that how it is for everybody?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Enough, Liz.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Enough of what?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I know I can't speak now because Laura's father died, and I just have to take it because otherwise I'm a bad guy, with the emphasis on guy, self-centered.  Well, I'm fucking not, not all the time, anyway, I'm really sorry Jo.  But you know, Liz... I can either stick up for myself or believe everything you say about me and end up hating myself.  And maybe you think I should, but it's not much of a life, you know?

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Maybe I've been a little unfair. But is this really the time?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Only because it's never the time.  I can't go on apologizing my whole life, you know?

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: If by "we" you are referring to men, then I have to say that just the once would do.

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: Good.  'Cause I'm enjoying myself.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: So you live in Chicago now?

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: Yup.  Not far from here, actually.

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: Don't you like that?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No, no, I love, it's just, thinking you're, you must be so sick of it... Well.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Hi, Marie.

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: Everything go alright?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: She just wanted to pick up some stuff. No big thing.  A relief, actually.

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: God, I hate that time.  That pick up stuff time.  I just went through that before I came here.  You know that song "Patsy Cline Times Two" I play?  That's about me and my ex dividing up our record collections.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It's a great song.

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Is that why you came to Chicago in the first place?  Because of, you know, dividing up your record collection and stuff?

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: Yup.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You share a place with T-Bone?

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: No way!  I'd cramp his style.  And I wouldn't want to listen to all that stuff happening on the other side of the bedroom wall.  I'm way to unattached for that.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I understand completely.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Awhile back, Dick and Barry and I agreed that what really matters is what you like, not what you are like...

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: Yeah, but if you heard this band called the Crumblers, you'd --

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: What do you mean, the Crumblers? You know the Crumblers?  Nobody's heard the Crumblers.  Except me.

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: Yeah, I know the Crumblers!  I bought a used Blasters album in New York about ten years ago and somebody left a Crumblers single in it.  My everything changed for a couple of weeks.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Books, records, films -- these things matter.  Call me shallow but it's the damn truth, and by this measure I was having one of the best dates of my life.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yeah, but you know what's his best film and nobody's even seen it?

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: The Conformist.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Exactly!  Fucking ex-actly!

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: You haven't even seen it!

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Nor have you!

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: Are you okay?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yes.  You?

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: For now.  But I wouldn't be if I thought this was the end of the evening.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'm sure it isn't.

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: Good.  In that case, I'll fix us something else to drink.  You sticking to the whiskey or you want coffee?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Whiskey.

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: Tops off two whiskeys and starts into the other room where she sees Rob, standing and holding his jacket.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'd better go.  I gotta get up early. Go over to my parents'.

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: When I said before that I hoped it wasn't the end of the evening, I was, you know... talking about breakfast and stuff.

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: I'd like it if you could stay the night.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Oh, right.  Alright.

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: Jesus, so much for delicacy.  I pegged you for a master of understatement, beating around the bush and all that buzz.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I use it but I don't understand it when other people use it.

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: So you'll stay?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Would you like me to turn the lights out?  Or would you like them on?

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: God, you ask a lot of questions.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Which way are you going?

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: That way.  You?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: That way.

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: And so it is.  I'll talk to you later.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'll call you.

turns.speaker: MARIE
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Hi, Rob.  It's your mother.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Hi, Mom.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Everything all right?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Great.  Super-fantastic.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: How's the store?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: So so.  Up and down.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Your lucky Laura's doing so well. If it wasn't for her, I don't think either of us would ever sleep...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: She left.  She's gone.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: What do you mean?  Where did she go?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: How would I know?  Gone.  Girlfriend. Leave.  Not say where gone.  Laura move out.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Well call her mother.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: She just called.  She doesn't even know.  It's probably the last time I'll ever hear her voice.  That's weird, isn't it?  You spend Christmas at somebody's house, you know, and you worry about their operations and you see them in their bathrobe, and... I dunno...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Hello?  Anybody there?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'm all right, if that's what's upsetting you.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: You know that's not what's upsetting me.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Well it fucking should be, shouldn't it?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: I knew this would happen.  What are you going to do Rob?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'm going to drink this bottle of wine watch TV and go to bed.  Then tomorrow I'll get up and go to work.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: And after that?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Meet a nice girl and have children. I promise the next time we talk I'll have it all sorted out.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: I knew this was going to happen.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Then what are you getting so upset about?

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: What did Laura say?  Do you know why she left?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It's got nothing to do with marriage, if that's what you're getting at.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: So you say.  I'd like to hear her side of it.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Mom!  For the last fucking time, I'm telling you Laura didn't want to get married!  She is not that kind of girl!  To use a phrase.  That's not what happens now.

turns.speaker: MOM
turns.text: Well I don't know what happens now, apart from you meet someone, you move in, she goes.  You meet someone, you move in, she goes.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It's the best collection I've ever seen.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Give me fifty bucks and they're all yours.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: These are worth at least, I don't know --

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: I know what they're worth.  Give me fifty and get them out.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: But you must have --

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: I must have nothing.  Their my husband's.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: And you must not be getting along too well right now, huh?

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: He's in Jamaica with a twenty-three- year-old.  A friend of my daughter's. He had the fucking nerve to call me and ask me to borrow some money and I told him to fuck off, so he asked me to sell his singles collection and send him a check for whatever I go, minus a ten percent commission. Which reminds me.  Can you make sure you give me a five?  I want to frame it and put it on the wall.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It must have taken him a long time to get them together.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Years.  This collection is as close as he's ever come to an achievement.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Look.  Can I pay you properly?  You don't have to tell him what you got. Send him forty-five bucks and blow the rest.  Give it to charity.  Or something.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: That wasn't part of the deal.  I want to be poisonous but fair.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Look... I... I'm sorry.  I don't want to be any part of this.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Suit yourself.  There are plenty of others who will.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: That's why I'm trying to compromise. What about fifteen-hundred?  They're worth five times that.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Sixty.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Thirteen hundred.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Seventy-five.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Eleven-hundred.  That's my lowest offer.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: And I won't take a penny over ninety.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: With eleven hundred he could come home, and that's the last thing I want.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'm sorry but I think you better talk to someone else.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Can I buy this Otis Redding single off you?

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Sure.  Ten cents.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Oh, come on!  Let me give you ten dollars for this, and you can give the rest away for all I care.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Okay.  Because you took the trouble to come up here.  And because you've got principles.  But that's it.  I'm not selling them to you one by one.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Eno import.  Sigue Sigue Sputnik. Break beats.  Serge Gainsbourg. Ryuchi Sakamoto, Syd Barrett... What's going on here?  Are you guys stealing for other people now?

turns.speaker: VINCE
turns.text: Naw.  Those are for us.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Oh really.  You two are slamming to Nico now?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I think you have more.

turns.speaker: VINCE
turns.text: Well we don't.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I can't frisk you but the cops can.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Jesus.  That thing's been in the bargain bin for six months!  Was it just your criminal nature or what? Hell, I would've given it to you for free.

turns.speaker: VINCE
turns.text: No, we...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Uh, yes I, like, do... It's simple. You make the tracks -- recording studio -- deliver them to the pressing plant where a master is cut, the master is then dubbed to submasters, which are the "mothers," as their called, for each press in the plant. You press the CD's or records, put in your cover art, and that's it.

turns.speaker: VINCE
turns.text: Records are those big round black things, right?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Fuck off.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: It's rough.  But it shows promise. We record a couple of songs right, in a studio.  I'll take care of the rest.  I'll put out your record. Any profits after recouping expenses get split down the middle, between us and you guys.

turns.speaker: VINCE
turns.text: Wait a minute.  Island Records charged U2 a million five against their overhead for one plane ride.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: We're not there yet, Justin.

turns.speaker: VINCE
turns.text: I'm Vince.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Whatever.

turns.speaker: VINCE
turns.text: We saw this ad in the personals for two swingers lookin' for a Renaissance fair.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Nice.

turns.speaker: VINCE
turns.text: What's the name of your label?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I can't figure out why he's doing it. He's been Richard Taupin at least since 1967.  And the guys rich.  You should see the stuff he has in that shop.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Maybe he's hiding from something.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Some guy named Smith was asking about him in Church Hill.  I passed his name around with your buddies downtown but they drew a blank.  So he isn't a cop.  District anyway.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Probably just some exec ducking an ex-wife.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Dr. Kidell had a picture in his file of the funeral.  The father looked just like Richard.  Even had a mark on his cheek.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: How old is Richard?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: P.D. says 41, but he barely looks 30.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Find the father.  That should clear things up.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Taupin, isn't that the guy Moran picked up the other night?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: He'd want to know about all this.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Mr. Congeniality?  Let him find his own clues.  There's a journal article in this somewhere.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Uncle Joey's little girl.  Can't get the taste out of her mouth.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: Well, the cream of society awaits.  If you're ever in the neighborhood...

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: DENNIS
turns.text: I warned you.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Go to hell.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Doesn't have a head, does he?

turns.speaker: EXAMINER
turns.text: This one came unassembled.

turns.speaker: EXAMINER
turns.text: How's your uncle?  I hardly ever see him anymore.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: EXAMINER
turns.text: Didn't look like it came from "Toys-Are-Us", that's why I called you.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Didn't think it was my buddy over there.

turns.speaker: EXAMINER
turns.text: Figured you knew more about swords than I did.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Claymore.

turns.speaker: EXAMINER
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Scottish claymore.  Take a French epee, add twenty pounds of ballast so it means business, and you've got a claymore.

turns.speaker: EXAMINER
turns.text: You're the expert.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: It's in good condition.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: That stuff'll put you away if you're not careful.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: There was a Count.  Count Dusan.  He would invite the local peasants to his chateau, fill them full of wine, then slice their bellies so he could reuse it.  The symmetry of that somehow always appealed to me.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: You're very macabre.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: It's my birthday.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Happy birthday.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: KIDELL
turns.text: Would you like more tea?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: No thank you, I'm fine.

turns.speaker: KIDELL
turns.text: He was unsual.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: KIDELL
turns.text: Well, this is a small town, and it was even smaller then.  Most all the babies I delivered were from local families.  Richard's parents were just passing through when his mother's time came.  I did it right here at the house.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Then you didn't know Richard later on.

turns.speaker: KIDELL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I've been trying to find somebody who knew him and any connections his family might have had with museums or historical societies.

turns.speaker: KIDELL
turns.text: Don't know about any of that. Suppose nobody does.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I don't follow you.

turns.speaker: KIDELL
turns.text: Poor little tyke didn't have a chance.  Hopelessly premature.  He died a few days after he was born.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: The boy _died_?

turns.speaker: KIDELL
turns.text: Mother too.  Sad case it was.  The young lady just couldn't make it through labor.  Never even saw her son.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Have you spoken to anyone else about this?

turns.speaker: KIDELL
turns.text: There was this one fella.  Asked a lot of questions.  I was out of town but I heard he spent near a full day in the records office.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Would you remember his name?

turns.speaker: KIDELL
turns.text: Carl Smith.

turns.speaker: DESK OFFICER
turns.text: This is against the rules.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: So's playing choo-choo with two high school cheerleaders in the middle of-

turns.speaker: DESK OFFICER
turns.text: -Okay okay.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: You owe me.  Besides, I'm cute.

turns.speaker: DESK OFFICER
turns.text: Taupin, Richard Marshall.  Born March 16, 1945 in Church Hill, Maryland.  Received first driver permit 1967 in Philadelphia.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Church Hill, that's pretty close, isn't it?

turns.speaker: DESK OFFICER
turns.text: Anything in Maryland is close.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Do you play?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Very traditional.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Miss Cartwright, what is it I can do for you?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I'd like to ask you about the claymore.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: It's not mine.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: It's quite rare you know, some- thing so common in its time so well looked after all these years.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Miss Cartwright, unless you have come here to sell the sword, there's very little I can help you with.  Now if you will excuse me, I have a great deal of work to do.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Byzantine?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Basil the II.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Charming guy, Basil.  Once after beating an army of Serbians he blinded all but-

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: -All but one out of a hundred, I know.  All left to be led like donkeys back home.  Now if you will please-

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Good reflexes.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Good day, Miss Cartwright.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Someone beat you.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Have you taken to touring small town cemetaries, Miss Cartwright?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Grave robbers?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Probably.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: People like that rarely leave business cards.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Does Carl Smith?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: I don't know what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I think you do.  Better yet, I don't think anything was stolen because nothing was there in the first place. And I think Mr. Smith, whoever he is, now knows that.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: You have an active imagination.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I've been to Church Hill.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Miss Cartwright, you are involving yourself in matters that do not concern you.  I strongly suggest you return to Washington and stay out of small town cemetaries.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I have friends.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: I doubt that.  Good day, Miss Cartwright.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Jesus Christ.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: You'll be safe here.  He won't kill in a church.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Tradition.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: What the hell is going on?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: He tried to kill me last night.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Dupont Circle.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Who is he?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: At the moment?  Carl Smith.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: And you?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: What will you do now?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: You needn't worry Miss Cartwright. I've been at this a very long time.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: He called you "MacLeod".

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Not your concern.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I left a man dead in Felton.  But you don't really care, do you?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: That bothers you?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: He was innocent.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: He's dead.  Whatever I may or may not feel means exceedingly little to him now.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: What about me?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: You?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I'm a witness to a murder.  That seems to put me pretty high on your friend's chop list.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Have you gone to the police?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Why not?  I'm sure they'd love to hear your story.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I'd rather hear yours.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: You are being foolish.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I'm a historian, Mr. Taupin. Only once in a lifetime do you stare history in the face.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Go home.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: He sees me as a threat.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Are you?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: No one knows you're here?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: No.  I had to talk to you.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: You had to do _nothing_!

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: You're wrong.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: You're a fool.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Is this what you killed them with?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: You've been listening to rumors.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Our cars were seen together in Felton.  They're calling me an accessory to murder.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: You are.  Now.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: What's all that?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Richard Taupin has become cumbersome.  It would be best if he just disappeared.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: You did kill those men.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Not all of them.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: When you finish, what then?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: I go my way and you can write all you want about the big bad Mr. Taupin.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: You make it all sound so simple.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: The only real difficulty comes in changing over the ownership of property I've aquired.  That requires certain records and most importantly a personal appearance at the county seat in Gettysburg.  But that's where you come in.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: You want me to front for you.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: The less exposure I recieve around government buildings the better.  You, as Mrs. Taupin, will attract considerably less attention than I.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: There was a man once.  Just a simple woodcarver.  But he understood.  More than anyone he could see to the heart of it.  It never ends.  Today is the same as the first.  Tomorrow will be the same as today.  So much time.  And all of it wasted.  You love history?

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: I wish I could.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: The estate stuff is pretty straight forward.  Just lots of forms and an appearance at the county seat.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: It will take some time for the forms to clear before you go to Gettysburg.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: No.  So what now?  We just wait?

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: Well, as long as we're stuck here.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: It's some sort of party the town is throwing.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: They do it each year.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: I thought it might be a nice break from all of this.

turns.speaker: TAUPIN
turns.text: Maybe it would do us both good.

turns.speaker: BRENNA
turns.text: There's a catch.  You're supposed to wear 19th century clothing.
